fled or got away from a place or situation

multiple_choice.question: What was the main reason James's parents went to London?
How did James's parents die?
What kind of house did James live in with his aunts?
What was the only tree in James's garden?

short_answer.question: Who took care of James after his parents died?
short_answer.answer: His aunts, Aunt Sponge and Aunt Spiker.

short_answer.question: Describe James's feelings while living with his aunts.
short_answer.answer: He felt sad, lonely, and unhappy because he was mistreated and had no friends or toys.

short_answer.question: What did James often do while standing at the bottom of the garden?
short_answer.answer: He gazed wistfully at the woods, fields, and ocean below him.

vocabulary.eng_definition: unusual or strange
in a wonderful or extraordinary way
very hot and bright
chairs used for relaxing outdoors, often on a deck or patio
drinking slowly or in small amounts
wet and soft in a way that is unpleasant
glasses worn to see better
cooked too much, resulting in a mushy texture
feeling very emotional or unable to cope
a small group of trees or bushes growing closely together

multiple_choice.question: What is James doing in the garden?
How does Aunt Sponge describe her face?
What does Aunt Spiker think she looks like?
How does James feel when he is working in the garden?

short_answer.question: Why does James begin to cry while working in the garden?
short_answer.answer: He feels lonely and unhappy because he wishes he could go to the seaside with his friends.

short_answer.question: What are Aunt Sponge and Aunt Spiker doing while James works?
short_answer.answer: They are sitting in deck-chairs, drinking lemonade, and talking about their appearances.

short_answer.question: How does James react when Aunt Spiker orders him to be beaten?
short_answer.answer: He looks at her with frightened eyes and runs away to hide.

vocabulary.eng_definition: strange or odd; unusual
the sound of things gently moving or rubbing together
shrubs or small trees growing close together
covered with or resembling stiff, short hairs or bristles
making a high-pitched, squeaking sound
emitting light; shining
affected by mold or fungus; damp and musty
solid substances with a regular, repeating internal structure
the ability or capacity to do something or act in a particular way
the use of supernatural powers to produce extraordinary effects

multiple_choice.question: What kind of suit was the old man wearing?
What was inside the small white paper bag?
What did the old man say about the green things in the bag?
options: They are worthless bits of glass
They have more magic and power than anything else in the world
multiple_choice.answer: They have more magic and power than anything else in the world

multiple_choice.question: What did the old man do just before giving the bag to James?
options: He waved his stick and jumped back
He showed him a magic trick
multiple_choice.answer: He waved his stick and jumped back

short_answer.question: Describe the old man's appearance.
short_answer.answer: He was a small old man with a huge bald head, a face covered with bristly black whiskers, and he wore a dark-green suit.

short_answer.question: What did the old man claim was in the bag?
short_answer.answer: He claimed it contained magical green stones or crystals that had more power than anything else in the world.

short_answer.question: What did the old man do right before giving the bag to James?
short_answer.answer: He waved his stick madly in the air and jumped back, showing excitement and mystery.

To swallow quickly or in large mouthfuls
Extraordinarily good or wonderful
Very unhappy or uncomfortable
Supernatural power that makes impossible things happen
To vanish from sight
To get away from a place or situation

multiple_choice.question: What should James do first according to the old man?
What will happen if James drinks the frothy water quickly?
options: He will feel churning and boiling in his stomach
multiple_choice.answer: He will feel churning and boiling in his stomach

multiple_choice.question: Why must James hold the bag tight?
options: To keep the green things inside
To prevent the magic from escaping
multiple_choice.answer: To prevent the magic from escaping

short_answer.question: What is the purpose of adding hairs from James's head to the water?
short_answer.answer: The hairs activate the magic of the green things in the water.

short_answer.question: What might happen if the green things escape from the bag?
short_answer.answer: They could use their magic on someone else instead of James.

multiple_choice.question: What does James try to do after falling in the grass?
What is Aunt Spiker's instruction to James?
What did James's treasures do when they hit the ground?
According to the old man's rule, who gets the full power of the magic?
options: The one who finds the most treasures

short_answer.question: Why was James feeling very sad at the end of the chapter?
short_answer.answer: Because he dropped his treasures and thought he would never have a happier life, only punishment and pain.

short_answer.question: What happened to the tiny green things after James dropped them?
short_answer.answer: They sank into the earth and disappeared quickly into the soil.

short_answer.question: What are some creatures living in the soil according to the chapter?
short_answer.answer: Earthworms, centipedes, and insects.

What are Aunt Sponge and Aunt Spiker planning to do with the peach?
What indicates that something unusual is happening?

short_answer.question: Why does James think something peculiar is about to happen?
short_answer.answer: Because he feels it in the air and notices everything is still and quiet.

short_answer.question: What does Aunt Spiker exclaim when she sees the peach growing?
short_answer.answer: She says, 'It's growing! It's getting bigger and bigger!'

short_answer.question: How does James react when he sees the peach start to grow?
short_answer.answer: He is amazed and watches closely as the peach bulges and swells.

hang or swing loosely

multiple_choice.answer: Butter yellow with pink and red patches

options: Eat a large piece of it
multiple_choice.answer: Eat a large piece of it

multiple_choice.question: How did James feel about the growing peach?

options: As tall and wide as a small house
multiple_choice.answer: As tall and wide as a small house

short_answer.question: Why were Aunt Sponge and Aunt Spiker cautious when inspecting the peach?
short_answer.answer: Because they were unsure if it was dead or alive and didn't want it to fall or break.

short_answer.question: Describe the appearance of the peach's skin.
short_answer.answer: The skin was a rich buttery yellow with patches of bright pink and red.

short_answer.question: What did Aunt Spiker suggest doing with the peach, and why?
short_answer.answer: She suggested getting a shovel to cut a piece of it for eating, because it was ripe and perfect for eating.

multiple_choice.question: Why did Aunt Sponge and Aunt Spiker build a fence around the peach?
How did the reporters and cameramen get into the hill?
What did James want to do while he was locked in his room?

short_answer.question: Why was James locked in his bedroom?
short_answer.answer: Because Aunt Spiker thought he would get in the way of the crowd and cause trouble.

short_answer.question: What did the aunts make James do after the crowd left?
short_answer.answer: They made him clean up the mess of banana skins, orange peel, and paper.

options: A hole in the side of the peach

multiple_choice.question: What is the moon doing in the sky?

short_answer.question: How does the garden look under the moonlight?
short_answer.answer: It looks soft, silver, and magical, with sparkling dew and shadows.

short_answer.question: What does James do when he reaches the giant peach?
short_answer.answer: He touches it gently and notices the hole in its side.

How did James feel when he saw the speakers?

short_answer.question: What does James discover about the hole he crawled into?
short_answer.answer: He discovers it is a tunnel leading toward the center of the peach.

short_answer.question: How does James react when he sees the speakers?
short_answer.answer: He is frightened and his face turns white with horror.

options: Because the creatures were large and frightening
multiple_choice.answer: Because the creatures were large and frightening

options: They are in the same situation
They are on a real boat
multiple_choice.answer: They are in the same situation

multiple_choice.question: What did the creatures say about hurting James?
options: They wanted to play a trick
They wouldn't dream of hurting him
multiple_choice.answer: They wouldn't dream of hurting him

short_answer.question: What is an insect? Give an example from the story.
short_answer.answer: An insect is a small creature, like a grasshopper. In the story, there was a large grasshopper that looked like a dog.

short_answer.question: Why was James so frightened when he saw the creatures?
short_answer.answer: Because the creatures were very large and looked frightening, especially in the greenish light.

short_answer.question: What does the phrase 'we're all in the same boat' mean?
short_answer.answer: It means that everyone is in the same situation or facing the same problem.

multiple_choice.question: What was the Centipede proud of?
options: Having a tiny stone or crystal

multiple_choice.question: What did the Earthworm say about having no legs?
options: It is impossible to move without legs
It is marvelous to have no legs and walk the same
multiple_choice.answer: It is marvelous to have no legs and walk the same

multiple_choice.question: What did the Old-Green-Grasshopper claim to be?
Why did the Ladybug smile at James?

short_answer.question: Why did James decide he liked the Centipede?
short_answer.answer: Because the Centipede was funny and made him laugh.

short_answer.question: What did the Centipede say about swallowing green things?
short_answer.answer: He said he swallowed three and others did too when they were in the garden.

short_answer.question: What did the Old-Green-Grasshopper want everyone to do at the end?
short_answer.answer: He wanted everyone to get some sleep because they had a tough day ahead.

options: It was a fly without wings that shined
multiple_choice.answer: It was a fly without wings that shined

multiple_choice.question: How did James feel about his new friends at the end of the chapter?

short_answer.question: What material did Miss Spider use to spin the hammock beds?
short_answer.answer: She used gossamer, a fine, silky thread.

short_answer.question: Why did the Centipede want the light turned out?
short_answer.answer: Because it was late at night and he wanted to sleep.

short_answer.question: What did James think of the Glow-worm's light?
short_answer.answer: He thought it looked like a giant fly with its tail on fire and was very bright.

options: The thick stem attaching it to the tree
multiple_choice.answer: The thick stem attaching it to the tree

multiple_choice.question: What kind of places does the Centipede say they might see?
What happens to Aunt Sponge and Aunt Spiker when the peach rolls over them?
options: They jump out of the way

short_answer.question: Why does the peach start to move?
short_answer.answer: Because the Centipede cuts the stem that attaches it to the tree.

short_answer.question: How do Aunt Sponge and Aunt Spiker react when they see the peach coming?
short_answer.answer: They scream, panic, and try to run away.

short_answer.question: What does the Ladybug say about the places they might visit?
short_answer.answer: She says they may see marvelous places and strange creatures, like dragons or unicorns.

short_answer.question: What is the final outcome for Aunt Sponge and Aunt Spiker?
short_answer.answer: They are crushed when the peach rolls over them.

multiple_choice.question: What did the peach break through at the beginning of the story?
What was flowing out of the factory after the peach went through?
What natural feature is described as being hundreds of feet high and located in England?
What happened to the peach when it reached the ocean?

short_answer.question: Why did animals in the countryside panic?
short_answer.answer: Because the peach was rolling through and knocking everything over, frightening the animals.

short_answer.question: What caused the chocolate factory to have holes in its wall?
short_answer.answer: The peach crashed through the factory wall, causing the melted chocolate to pour out.

short_answer.question: What is the significance of the White Cliffs in the story?
short_answer.answer: They are the famous cliffs that the peach was approaching before falling into the ocean, symbolizing the end of its journey.

options: Something went wrong with the Glow-worm's lighting system
multiple_choice.answer: Something went wrong with the Glow-worm's lighting system

options: He wanted his boots on first
He didn't want to get his boots dirty
multiple_choice.answer: He wanted his boots on first

options: She set about weaving a rope-ladder
multiple_choice.answer: She set about weaving a rope-ladder

options: At the bottom of a coal mine
At the top of a mountain
multiple_choice.answer: At the bottom of a coal mine

short_answer.question: What was the main problem during the journey inside the peach?
short_answer.answer: They experienced chaos, being flung around and in darkness due to the tumbling and the broken lighting system.

short_answer.question: How did the characters finally see after the room went dark?
short_answer.answer: The Glow-worm’s tail glimmered with a faint greenish light that gradually grew stronger.

short_answer.question: What did the characters plan to do after the chaos ended?
short_answer.answer: They decided to go upstairs and look around from the top of the peach.

options: They are safe and have food
multiple_choice.answer: They are safe and have food

short_answer.answer: They are relieved and happy because they realize they are floating and safe.

short_answer.answer: He suggests they eat parts of the peach for food.

short_answer.question: What do the characters enjoy about the peach at the end?
short_answer.answer: They enjoy the delicious taste of the peach and feel happy.

short_answer.question: Why does the Centipede burst into song?
short_answer.answer: Because he is excited about how delicious the peach is and wants to share his joy.

They are trapped in a cave

short_answer.question: Why are the characters afraid of the sharks?
short_answer.answer: Because the sharks are attacking the peach and they fear they will be eaten.

short_answer.question: What does Miss Spider want James to do?
short_answer.answer: She wants James to think of a way to escape from the sharks.

multiple_choice.question: What is James planning to do with the seagulls?
options: Use them to lift the peach out of the water
Use them to carry a message
multiple_choice.answer: Use them to lift the peach out of the water

options: To lift the peach out of the water
multiple_choice.answer: To lift the peach out of the water

multiple_choice.question: What does James use as bait for the seagulls?
What is the main obstacle James faces in his plan?
options: Getting the string to be strong enough
multiple_choice.answer: Getting the string to be strong enough

short_answer.question: Why does James think seagulls are suitable for lifting the peach?
short_answer.answer: Because seagulls have more lifting power than balloons, and there are many of them available.

short_answer.question: What is James's plan for using the seagulls to lift the peach?
short_answer.answer: He plans to loop a string around each seagull's neck, tie it to the peach stem, and use enough seagulls to lift the peach out of the water.

short_answer.question: Why does the Earthworm refuse to be bait?
short_answer.answer: Because he is afraid of being pecked to death by the seagulls.

short_answer.answer: He wanted them to spin silk quickly to save their lives.

short_answer.question: Describe how the peach is described as balancing at the end of the story.
short_answer.answer: It is like a delicately balanced scale that needs only a tiny push to tip one way or the other.

short_answer.question: What was the final outcome for the giant peach?
short_answer.answer: It rose majestically out of the water, climbing toward the heavens like a golden balloon.

multiple_choice.answer: She jumped off with a silk thread

Their long noses made it impossible for them to bite the smooth surface
They were afraid of the spiders
multiple_choice.answer: Their long noses made it impossible for them to bite the smooth surface

What was the captain of the ship worried about?

That they would run out of fuel
multiple_choice.answer: That the round object was a secret weapon

multiple_choice.question: What did the captain see through the telescope?

short_answer.question: Why did Miss Spider say the damage to the peach was minimal?
short_answer.answer: Because the sharks' teeth couldn't really damage the smooth surface of the peach.

short_answer.question: What did the sharks do that made the others think they caused damage?
short_answer.answer: They churned the water into froth and opened and shut their mouths, which looked like damage.

short_answer.question: Why did the characters think they were sinking?
short_answer.answer: They might have imagined it because sharks couldn't actually damage the peach.

short_answer.question: What was the captain's reaction to seeing the round object?
short_answer.answer: He thought it was a secret weapon and wanted to warn the country.

informal word for stomach

multiple_choice.question: What musical instrument does the Old-Green-Grasshopper play?
Why does the Old-Green-Grasshopper say he is a 'short-horn' grasshopper?
What does the centipede think about ears on the sides of the head?

short_answer.question: How does the Old-Green-Grasshopper produce music?
short_answer.answer: He uses his back leg as a bow and the edge of his wing as strings, like a violin.

short_answer.question: Where do the 'long-horned' grasshoppers keep their ears?
short_answer.answer: In their legs, just below the knees.

short_answer.question: What does the Old-Green-Grasshopper say about things we haven't wondered about yet?
short_answer.answer: He says there are many things in the world that we haven't started wondering about.

vocabulary.eng_definition: Very unusual or remarkable.

Causing horror or fear; ghostly.
To prod or push with a finger or object.
To laugh quietly and disrespectfully.
To change or modify.

multiple_choice.question: What does the Earthworm do that is considered extraordinary?
options: It passes soil through its body
multiple_choice.answer: It passes soil through its body

multiple_choice.question: Why do farmers love Ladybugs?
What is a common misconception about Ladybugs?
options: You can tell their age by spots
multiple_choice.answer: You can tell their age by spots

multiple_choice.question: What does Miss Spider do that is helpful?
What is the Centipede proud of?

short_answer.question: Why does the Earthworm say it passes soil through its body?
short_answer.answer: To help farmers make the soil light and crumbly so plants can grow well.

short_answer.question: How do Ladybugs help farmers?
short_answer.answer: They eat harmful insects that damage crops.

short_answer.question: What is the significance of the spots on a Ladybug?
short_answer.answer: They show which branch of the family the Ladybug belongs to; they do not change with age.

short_answer.question: Why is the Centipede proud of being a pest?
short_answer.answer: Because it helps keep harmful insects away and considers it a valuable role.

vocabulary.eng_definition: balancing unsteadily, wobbling
the edge of something, especially something dangerous
falling or rolling over and over
completely soaked with water
to pull or drag with effort
a large amount of water covering an area

a joyful occasion or gathering to honor something
highly valued or loved
free from danger or harm

multiple_choice.question: What caused the Centipede to fall from the peach?
options: He was pushed by other insects
He went too close to the edge and teetered
multiple_choice.answer: He went too close to the edge and teetered

multiple_choice.question: How did James rescue the Centipede?
options: He tied himself to the silk and climbed down
He pushed him off the peach
multiple_choice.answer: He tied himself to the silk and climbed down

multiple_choice.question: What was the Old-Green-Grasshopper playing during the sad moment?
Why did Miss Spider suggest going below the peach?
options: To stay warm and safe overnight
Because it was too dark outside
multiple_choice.answer: To stay warm and safe overnight

short_answer.question: Why was everyone crying at the end of the chapter?
short_answer.answer: They were crying because the Centipede fell and everyone was sad about him.

short_answer.question: How did James find the Centipede after he fell?
short_answer.answer: James swam in the Atlantic Ocean to find him and pulled him up with the silk.

short_answer.question: What do the characters decide to do at the end of the chapter?
short_answer.answer: They decide to stay up on the peach through the night and keep watch for safety.

vocabulary.eng_definition: Very intense or powerful; too much to handle.

Moved slowly and smoothly through the air or water.

Tools for digging or moving loose material.
Broken or split with a line.
Shaking slightly, usually from fear or cold.
A dark shape seen against a brighter background.

multiple_choice.question: What was floating along during the night in the story?
What did the Cloud-Men use to make hailstones?
Why did James tell the Centipede to be quiet?
options: Because the Cloud-Men might hear him
multiple_choice.answer: Because the Cloud-Men might hear him

multiple_choice.question: What did the Cloud-Men do when they saw the peach?
What was the Cloud-Men practicing for?

short_answer.question: What did the Cloud-Men do with the cloud bits?
short_answer.answer: They rolled them into marbles and threw them into space.

short_answer.question: How did the Cloud-Men react when the Centipede yelled at them?
short_answer.answer: They jumped and looked surprised, then started throwing hailstones.

short_answer.question: Why did James and his friends go inside the peach's tunnel?
short_answer.answer: Because the Cloud-Men were throwing hailstones and it was dangerous outside.

short_answer.question: What did the seagulls do when the Cloud-Men started throwing hailstones?
short_answer.answer: They pulled the peach away and helped protect James and his friends.

so fascinated that one cannot think or focus clearly

options: He was carried by a seagull
multiple_choice.answer: He was carried by a seagull

multiple_choice.question: What did the Cloud-Men throw at the travelers?
options: Objects like paint buckets and rotten eggs
multiple_choice.answer: Objects like paint buckets and rotten eggs

multiple_choice.question: Why did the Centipede scream with anger?
options: He was covered in paint and couldn’t move
multiple_choice.answer: He was covered in paint and couldn’t move

short_answer.question: Why did the travelers think the rainbow was special?
short_answer.answer: Because it was being painted by Cloud-Men and was very colorful and beautiful.

short_answer.question: How did James and his friends manage to save themselves from the Cloud-Man?
short_answer.answer: The Centipede bit through the silk string, causing the Cloud-Man to be pulled away by a seagull.

short_answer.question: What caused the rainbow to break into two pieces?
short_answer.answer: The peach crashed into the rainbow, snapping it in the middle.

short_answer.question: What was the biggest challenge the travelers faced on the cloud?
short_answer.answer: They had to avoid the Cloud-Men who threw objects at them and tried to catch the peach.

very bad or miserable

making a bubbling or splashing sound
hate intensely
with the top at the bottom
removing the outer layer

options: He will turn into a statue
multiple_choice.answer: He will turn into a statue

multiple_choice.question: What was James's reaction at the end of the passage?

short_answer.question: Why did Miss Spider feel sorry for the Centipede?
short_answer.answer: Because he was covered in rainbow-paint and looked very stiff and hurt.

short_answer.question: What humorous idea did the Earthworm suggest for removing the paint?
short_answer.answer: Pulling out his tongue and turning him inside out.

short_answer.question: What does the phrase 'inside out' mean in this context?
short_answer.answer: Turning the Centipede so that his inner side is facing outward, like turning his skin inside out.

options: They shrieked with fear and groped for something to hold
multiple_choice.answer: They shrieked with fear and groped for something to hold

multiple_choice.question: What did the Centipede do after the storm stopped?

short_answer.question: What was the main cause of the storm in the story?
short_answer.answer: The cloud opened and released a huge mass of water, causing a storm.

short_answer.question: How did the characters react to being caught in the rain?
short_answer.answer: They shrieked with fear, groped for something to hold, and felt overwhelmed by the rain.

short_answer.question: What change happened to the Centipede after the rainstorm?
short_answer.answer: The Centipede was washed clean, could move again, and was very happy.

multiple_choice.question: What are the Cloud-Men doing in their city?

What are the Cloud-Men's wives doing at the cave entrances?

short_answer.question: Why are the seagulls flying faster and faster?
short_answer.answer: They want to get out of the stormy area because they are frightened.

short_answer.question: What does the travelers see as the sun rises?
short_answer.answer: They see the sun coming up over the horizon, marking a new day.

multiple_choice.question: What did the characters see from the peach?

short_answer.question: Why do the characters think they are in America?
short_answer.answer: Because they see skyscrapers and realize they crossed the Atlantic Ocean overnight.

short_answer.question: What is the plan to get down from the sky?
short_answer.answer: They plan to cut loose seagulls so they can descend slowly and gently, with the help of the Centipede biting through the strings.

multiple_choice.question: What was seen hovering over Manhattan in Chapter 33?
options: A round ball as big as a house
multiple_choice.answer: A round ball as big as a house

multiple_choice.question: What did the people in New York do when they saw the hovering object?
options: Looked up and ran for the subway
multiple_choice.answer: Looked up and ran for the subway

multiple_choice.question: Who did the Mayor of New York call for help?
options: The President of the United States
multiple_choice.answer: The President of the United States

short_answer.question: What was the people’s reaction to the hovering object?
short_answer.answer: They panicked and ran for cover, heading to the subway.

short_answer.question: Why was the alarm sounded across all fifty states?
short_answer.answer: Because everyone was warned about the huge bomb hovering over New York City, which might go off at any moment.

short_answer.question: Why was the peach losing height gradually?
short_answer.answer: Because the strings holding it were cut by the plane, causing it to fall.

short_answer.question: What was the animals' reaction when they saw the plane?
short_answer.answer: They cried out for help and realized they were losing control of the peach.

multiple_choice.question: What was falling from the sky in the story?

short_answer.question: What was the main event happening in the story?
short_answer.answer: A large peach was falling rapidly towards the earth, causing panic among the people.

short_answer.question: How did the people feel during the final moments of the story?
short_answer.answer: They were holding their breath and waiting anxiously for what would happen next.

short_answer.question: What does the word 'pinnacle' mean in the story?
short_answer.answer: It means the highest point or peak, in this case the top of the Empire State Building.

short_answer.question: Why was the top of the tallest skyscraper described as tapered?
short_answer.answer: Because it gradually narrowed into a sharp point, like a needle.

options: It can light up without electricity
multiple_choice.answer: It can light up without electricity

multiple_choice.question: What was the crowd’s reaction when the children’s creatures were introduced?

short_answer.question: Why did the policemen and firemen faint?
short_answer.answer: They fainted because they saw the scary-looking creatures like the Scorpula and Knid.

short_answer.question: What did James say about the creatures’ origins?
short_answer.answer: James said they came from thousands of miles away, from outer space.

short_answer.question: How did James describe the Earthworm?
short_answer.answer: He said the Earthworm is good for digging land and making soils better.

short_answer.question: What was the reaction of the crowd when the creatures were introduced?
short_answer.answer: They cheered, clapped, and showed excitement for the creatures.

short_answer.question: What did James want the policemen and firemen to do at the end?
short_answer.answer: He wanted them to believe that the creatures were friendly and not dangerous.

short_answer.question: Why did everyone become a hero in the story?
short_answer.answer: Because they helped bring the giant peach to New York and made the celebration possible.

short_answer.question: What did James tell the children about the peach?
short_answer.answer: He told them they could eat all they wanted because it wouldn't last forever.

short_answer.question: How did the children react to the giant peach?
short_answer.answer: They were very excited, ran onto the truck, and started eating it, chasing after it in a long trail.

multiple_choice.question: Who did the Ladybug marry?
options: The Head of the Fire Department
multiple_choice.answer: The Head of the Fire Department

short_answer.question: Where is the peach stone monument located?
short_answer.answer: It is located in Central Park.

short_answer.question: Why did James decide to write his story as a book?
short_answer.answer: Because many children loved hearing about his adventures and he wanted to share his story.
